content.title: Chandrasekhar Limit and the Planck Mass
content.summary: The Chandrasekhar limit—the maximum mass of a white dwarf star—can be derived from the Planck mass and the proton mass. This striking connection shows how fundamental scales determine stellar structure.

derivation.physical_principle: Balance between gravitational collapse and electron degeneracy pressure

steps.description: Gravitational energy for star of mass M, radius R
Fermi energy of degenerate electrons (N ~ M/m_p electrons)
Total Fermi energy of all electrons
Relativistic limit: v_F → c, so E_F ~ p_F c ~ ℏc/R × (M/m_p)^(1/3)

numerical_calculation.note: Order-of-magnitude estimate gives correct answer within factor of 2

stellar_evolution: White dwarfs with M > M_Ch cannot be supported by electron degeneracy
Leads to Type Ia supernovae (standard candles for cosmology)

planck_connection.insight: Stellar structure is determined by ratio m_P/m_p
planck_connection.generalization: Maximum neutron star mass M_NS ~ m_P³/m_n² ~ 2-3 M_☉

physical_significance.dimensionless_physics: The Chandrasekhar limit depends only on dimensionless ratio m_P/m_p and fundamental constants
